posts.com:
Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

If you are looking to get advice on a possible car purchase or car related problem, be sure to include:

What car or cars you are looking at or as detailed a description of the problem as possible. Include make, model, year, mileage, condition, any know faults, the asking price, and what your budget is!

If people have to ask you for every detail, you aren't going to get many replies!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars

posts.com: Even being a technology famed by unreliability related to oil consumption, how was the Mazda R26B engine from the 787B be able to finish the 1991 24 Hours of Le Mans unscattered?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26253814
They're not really unreliable. They just require rebuilds more often than a typical piston engine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26253814
Wankels need to meet very specific operating conditions to not be unreliable. Race conditions meet those, that's why Wankel Mazda owners who track and have fun with their cars will say it's average reliability, while those who daily it will say it's unreliable and eats apex seals. And that's why Mazda will make a Wankel range extender for the MX30. (the sole purpose of that engine will be to drive a generator, so it can run under perfect conditions all the time).

Also wankels burn oil by design. You need to be mindful of that and refill oil.

Also you don't have to worry about either smog or mpg in a race car, and you can simply inject oil and burn it to lubricate the seals. You can refill oil in the pit if you need to, or carry enough of it to last the race.

>>26254801
In Dienstanfängerkreisen kommen immer wieder Verwechslungen der Begriffe "Wertsack", "Wertbeutel", "Versackbeutel" und "Wertpaketsack" vor.
Um diesem Übel abzuhelfen ist das folgende Merkblatt dem § 49 der ADA vorzuheften.

Der Wertsack ist ein Beutel, der aufgrund seiner besonderen Verwendung im Postbeförderungsdienst nicht Wertbeutel, sondern Wertsack genannt wird, weil sein Inhalt aus mehreren Wertbeuteln besteht, die in den Wertsack nicht verbeutelt, sondern versackt werden.

Das ändert aber nichts an der Tatsache, dass die zur Bezeichung des Wertsackes verwendete Wertbeutelfahne auch bei einem Wertsack mit Wertbeutelfahne bezeichnet wird und nicht mit Wertsackfahne, Wertsackbeutelfahne oder Wertbeutelsackfahne.

Sollte es soch bei der Inhaltsfeststellung eines Wertsackes herausstellen, dass ein in einen Wertsack versackter Versackbeutel statt im Wertsack in einen der im Wertsack versackten Wertbeutel hätte versackt werden müssen, so ist die in Frage kommende Versackstelle unverzüglich zu benachrichtigen.

Nach seiner Entleerung wird der Wertsack wieder zum einem Beutel, und er ist auch bei der Beutelzählung nicht als Sack, sondern als Beutel zu zählen.

Bei einem im Ladezettel mit dem Vermerk "Wertsack" eingetragenen Beutel handelt es sich jedoch nicht um einen Wertsack, sondern um einen Wertpaketsack, weil ein Wertsack im Ladezettel nicht als solcher bezeichnet wird, sondern lediglich durch den Vermerk "versackt" darauf hingewiesen wird, dass es sich bei dem versackten Wertbeutel um einen Wertsack und nicht um einen ausdrücklich mit "Wertsack" bezeichneten Wertpaketsack handelt.

Verwechslungen sind insofern im übrigen ausgeschlossen, als jeder Postangehörige weiß, dass ein mit Wertsack bezeichneter Beutel kein Wertsack, sondern ein Wertpaketsack ist.

>>26254078
The normie adage is that "Flying is remarkably safer than driving per mile".
That's true, but it's true for all flights, which are overwhelmingly on commercial carriers. The General Aviation (and below, i.e. experimentals, sport, ultralight, glide, etc) classes have a record more akin to motorcycles, or *worse*. However, one counterpoint is that GA *includes* things like aerobatic aircraft and some other risky shit. Suffice it to say, you need to keep your head about you like you're hooning around like a fool on a crotch rocket, because the stats put you somewhere in that ballpark of danger. Is most of it driven by complacent pilots who don't watch for other aircraft and collide and fucking die, because in a collision in the air, you don't get to dump the bike and skid, and you instead drop to the fucking Earth? Probably. But, familiarity always breeds complacency. And just like in biker circles, they say "well y'know, I trust MYSELF, but, I don't trust OTHER people on the road!", you need to always be watching and assuming stupidest intentions. Keep your eyes outside the cockpit fren.
-t. working on a PPL in 172s

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I did rear locker, because toyota lsd's are open diff's in disguise. It's a different animal now, not only can it do circle work, but it won't ever do the dreaded rocking horse (drive over rock, spin front left - rear right, go nowhere) again. It'll go places in 2wd that i used to have to lock in for. Oh, and, like above, skids. I'll eventually twin lock, probably, idk, maybe. There's some downsides to twin lock and front locked.
Just keep in mind... you'll forever be driving around it, it's more of a auto unlocker, than an auto locker, in that it's basically a weldie unless the clutch is in, then it ratchets.

Any locker is better than no locker.

I went front first. The rare situation where the front locker isn't enough on it's own, I can simply apply the e-brake at 50% to get both back wheels spinning and that works like a charm.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26251641
This is true, in 4x4 you'll get the same 3x4 result front or rear locked. I just got sick of getting stuck on a banana peel in 2wd, i mean it was bad, you'd have called it a loose diff even if it was an open diff. Raw capability has skyrocketed in 2wd and 4wd with it.
I've got manual locking front hubs, but, not sure i 'want' a front locker yet for two reasons, heavier steering (more sand dunes here than rock crawling) and i don't have rubbers on my drive shafts to absorb torque, so not sure i want to load up the xfer case that hard. Plus, like you i've got a winch.

posts.name: BigC
posts.com:
>>26251644
clicky boy

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26251649
Yeah here it's steep climbs on loose/rocky surfaces. The front locker pulls you up and over in that situation. In sand I can see the rear locker being better.

I will say though that all of the "you wont be able to steer" posts from people were unfounded. I did preemptively beef up my steering system with an idler arm brace and modified the center link for stability, but steering hasn't been an issue at all. You get more feedback through the wheel but it's not like people were saying it would be. The stock power steering pump has been more than enough to handle it.

There are also people who say "you'll break CVs" but haven't had an issue with that either. I'd say you'd break more CVs running open front because youre spinning a loose wheel very fast and then suddenly it will find traction and shock load the axle. With the locker everything is more measured.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Pennzoil NISMO GT-R invasion at 2001 NISMO FESTIVAL!

2001 was a rad year! It was a rare and unique opportunity to see all the Pennzoil-sponsored NISMO GT500 cars together. And let me tells you: the legendary american oil brand stopped to sponsor one of two NISMO official team chassis in 2000 JGTC season, but returned to 2001 for sponsor the ex-LOCTITE ZEXEL GT-R car, becoming the ‘Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R’ that year. Different from the 1998 R33, and 1999 R34 Pennzoil GT500 champions, and even helping NISMO to win the 2001 season on team standings along with the sister chassis, the Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R has been updated to ‘Castrol PITWORK GT-R’ for 2002, losing the yellow livery and the Pennzoil sponsor once again. So yes, it means that the Pennzoil ZEXEL GT-R is no longer around us.

Another curious fact, , is that the Pennzoil NISMO GT-R BCNR33 and BNR34 pictured here aren’t “original” cars, but replica based on other chassis. Respectively, they are the 1998 ZEXEL SKYLINE and 1999 CALSONIC SKYLINE repainted as Pennzoil-sponsored cars for NISMO’s heritage.

The original Pennzoil BCNR33 has the low-downforce kit and Nicos GT banner and sometimes can be seen appearing in some events, including the NISMO FESTIVAL itself. The original Pennzoil BNR34 however, has been lost. It was upgraded to ‘Castrol NISMO GT-R’ for 2000 JGTC season, but the car crashed in the first round, being replaced by a new bespoke chassis. NISMO took the IMPUL’s BNR34 late that year to replicate the 1999 JGTC GT500 drivers champion.

>>26241445
Yes. There was a short period of time in the late 80s and early 90s where it was approaching mainstream popularity, but it died pretty quickly because the championship started to be dominated by foreign drivers and they started moving away from the Oval roots. IRL broke away to try and avoid the problems CART had, but the competing championships ended up dividing viewership more (with the people who wanted ovals and American drivers all jumping ship to NASCAR which was at its peak of popularity then, and the people who didn’t mind the internationalism just went to F1). Nowadays the only people who care about Indy are midwesterners, and even then it’s really only the Indy 500.

>>26242427
I think I get why the games seem to fall apart, the hierarchal structure of frostbite makes changing one thing very complicated if it's not like a single float value or something. There's no real way to just turn UI elements off and on, everything you want needs to be written down all the way up the ladder.
For example the way the controls work is strange: the game identifies and has separate mappings for different types of controllers but instead of just saying internally "ok button 1 for controller 1 is gas, button 2 is brake, controller 1 is not an Xbox pad so I will use the steering wheel handling rules" they let the game engine figure out specifically what kind of controller you're using and map "concepts" to "actions" then to a generic layout that is pre-set with all the buttons and axes the game should expect to see for each supported controller, It seemingly has no idea what the actual controller axes and buttons are, probably why heat needed g-hub for any wheels to work.

shit is stupid and is a good example of why big game companies and monolithic multipurpose engines were a mistake
all the dumb fucks that could have put a button rebinding menu in NFS are busy rescuing Battlefield

Announcing /ovg/ Sunday Cup - an upcoming (no firm date yet but expect February) series in Assetto Corsa where you pick and choose your own car.

Rules are a little bit complicated for this one so read the wiki: http://wiki.get-good.net/index.php?title=/ovg/_Sunday_Cup but the tl;dr for you is this: Find a car listing in the permitted countries with a car worth at most 2000 euros, and a maximum of 200 bhp. Submit this car to the (temporary) doc below and get it approved for entry. Beware! You may ONLY choose a car noone else has chosen the same body style of, ie. you can have a BMW E92 and a BMW E30 in the series, but no two BMW E92s regardless of type. Read the wiki for in-depth rules.

https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1vlVjNh8r6o_KYUFHf7Hcp8ZaYS5lsEZwFvTeu_K_c1Q/edit#gid=515811564

Indians have given us some cheap yet decent performance lower displacement bikes though. China hasn't. Chinese small displacement bikes are basically bad middleweights with tiny engines. Chinese have some middleweights, which are cheaper than a new Japanese middleweight, but don't have value compared to a tried and true used Japanese middleweight. CFMoto has KTM motors yes, but probably detuned, and it seems, on considerably higher chassis when people mostly buy KTMs for the light weight and high strung motors, not because KTM engine designs are good or reliable.

I'd consider a CFmoto if I needed a middleweight and it had to be new or ADV and I couldn't afford Japanese, but that's about it. For the weight, I'd rather have Japanese. If I had the money, I might grumble about Euro bikes made in Asia, but the premium Euro versions have better suspension and weight than the Japanese, where the Chinese ones tend to be worse. It's the same engine, but I wouldn't buy a KTM for the engine, I'd buy a KTM for the entire package.

WHY are you waiting for the revs to drop before releasing the clutch on a higher gear? If the revs drop too low you get a jolt and an unresponsive shaky engine response killing the low-end. >>26250536
Third iteration / generation. The MK1 TT was the bubbly one. The MK2 was pic related. OP pic is a MK3. Basically to become a different iteration / generation and bump up a "mk", there has to be significant enough changes to the platform, styling and drivetrain to make it such over just being regarded as a "facelift", which is mid iteration / generation restyling tweak to refresh an old platform.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26251819

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26251819
Oh, and the actual term "Mark" as a descriptor / designation comes from the military to describe weapons and vehicle engineering. This is abbreviated to "MK". If something is a MK I it is the first generation. The first tank in WW1 was the British MK I. Little Boy was a MK I atomic weapon. Et cetera.

As far as the big 3 truckmakers go in the US, here’s how it goes. Bear in mind I’m going off of ~2010 onwards, things have changed since the turn of the century.

Ford — usually the most powerful trucks in their class, questionable quality control
Ram — care way more about being a luxury vehicle than being a truck in the half ton models. 3/4 ton and up are just as good as Ford for real work. Better quality control than Ford, which is the complete opposite of 20 years ago
Chevrolet/GMC — highway princesses. I’ve seen plenty of Fords, Rams, and Toyotas at jobsites and on ranches. Never seen a Chevy at a jobsite. Ironically, the Ram 1500 would make a much better mallcrawler than the Silverado or Sierra.

They did. It costs. Various manufacturers have built aluminium cars since the late 19th century. But they were bespoke and/or low volume coach builds for ladder frames. Aluminium panels were more common in the mid 20th century. I think the Honda NSX was the first all aluminium car back in the late 80s. Then Audi did it for the A8 in the mid 90s. Jaguar was also the first to produce a carbon fibre monocoque car for the road with the XJR15 in 1990 (the guy who designed the XJR15 body went off to McLaren and co-designed the F1 which came two years later).

>>26252718
Audi did with the A8 D2, and the A2. While successive generations of Audi A8 are marketed as Audi Space Frame, it contains less and less aluminium with each generation. Even steel Audis (up to the 2008 recession) are reputable for their corrosion resistance (fully galvanized) IF they are correctly repaired when Karen hits them with her SUV.

Lessons learned with aluminium was:
> You need a space frame chassis, since it's not strong enough for monocoque
> With a space frame you can make the chassis stronger than steel would be
> Aluminium is fucking light, it makes cars light (an a8 d2 with interior delete is around 1500 kg kerb, 1700-1900 kg stock, and we didn't talk carbon, since you can replace all paneling if you have the cash for it, the space frame is responsible for keeping the car together), and it makes fun cars
> Aluminium DOES NOT RUST. Ever.
> Aluminium is a bitch to work with in the plant
> Aluminium is a bitch to repair when dented (cost 10x as much as the steel repair would)
> Aluminium is more expensive than steel, so cheap cars are off the menu

With the current EV craze, you need an aluminium/carbon space frame aerodynamic EV. (BMW one upped this, the i3 was made of fucking carbon 189 miles out of 42 kWh battery)
> the space frame is responsible for holding the batteries
> You can pull the wires inside the frame
> passive crash rating off the charts
> Do a light interior and it will be 2-300 kg lighter than the competitor
> Now you can start derating the engine and deleting batteries while keeping the range

If I had infinite $$$, I would EV swap a D2. Problem is that it could only be done if you have infinite $$$

It tries to behave like a manual transmission. When you mash the gas all of a sudden, you're basically requesting the car to accelerate hard, which requires a lower gear. In a manual, are you going to downshift, floor for half a second, downshift again, floor for half a second, and downshift again? posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26248464
>once the demand rises
This gets overplayed. Every gallon of gas burned to drive 25 miles in the average ICE vehicle today took about 6kWh of electricity to get into the fuel tank for that to happen.
6kWh put into a typical 4 mile a kWh BEV today will go 24 miles on that same 6kWh. So if every vehicle on the road was magically a BEV tomorrow, demand would only increase marginally.

With 5 and 6 mile a kWh BEVs coming to market, demand may actually decrease slightly. A 6 mile a kWh BEV would drive 36 miles on the same 6kWh. More efficient BEVs are also more practical for owners to run on their own solar generation with some designs where the solar panels are integrated into the vehicle able to add about their needed daily use when parked out in the sun.

>It is highly unlikely that charging once a week will be enough, especially as the cars gets older.
Even a 70% degraded long range car at the end of its life will still have more range than a short range car. Charging once a week overnight, or a couple of times a week for 1 hour in the middle of the night really just comes down to personal preference and the cost of electricity. Its probably cheaper to charge a couple of times a week for 1 hour, than for a few hours less frequently.

>while charging it overnight is a sound strategy, can you guarantee that that will be enough?
For the vast majority of daily use and weekend trips? Yes. Keep in mind that 250 mile range is pretty typical for affordable BEVs today, and the whole reason gas cars have 300 miles of range is so they can go about 2 weeks in normal use without refueling.
One night a week, or one hour periodically can easily cover daily use, and when you make a longer drive? Its just an overnight charge to be back up to full.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26248544
>How do you figure?
Refineries have electrical use measured in terrawatt hours, more than some whole cities. The pumps that extract oil from the ground, and move it in pipelines also use significant amounts of electricity. Then of course gas stations have to keep their lights on, and they also use electric pumps to move the fuel up into your gas tank.
6kWh is actually the low end of estimates. At the high end BEVs already use less electricity than even really exceptional internal combustion vehicles.

The TLDR is that the switch over to BEVs is probably only going to be a small part of the necessary grid upgrades that will be done over the next 30+ years as old dirty coal is phased out in favor of modern safe and clean Nuclear power.

That's why. Gas is lightweight, but getting it to do useful work with a reasonable amount of power in a modern car requires a lot of weight.
Battery electric powertrains are the opposite, batteries are big and heavy, but getting power out of them and onto the road is easy and electric motors are pretty compact and not very heavy.

A modern BEV like the Mercedes EQXX has a powertrain that weighs about what your idealized 'engine transmission and fuel tank with 500 miles of range', but can drive 600+ miles.
600 miles on 3 gallon equivalent is 200 mpge. Call it 500 miles of range in winter, and that's still 166mpge.

The most efficient gas vehicle ever (which was itself a PHEV in range-extender mode) could only manage 100mpge in optimal conditions. And it was a small 2 seater as seen here: >>26248754

But effectivity anon isn't doing a good job.
Effectivity anon is arguing that since BEVs are more effective, it would make more sense to burn the gasoline and diesel in huge generators since the thermal effectivity is almost double for gasoline and a bit higher for diesel, while the net loss from generator to BEV battery is insignificant.

This has remained true since at the least 1880s, but it does not matter if you can't get big enough batteries.
What happened between the 1910s to 1930s was that gasoline engines finally got effective and reliable enough to become dominant. And if we finally got solid state batteries during this decade, and they aren't insanely expensive, I honestly expect most of the applications for ICE to become irrelevant due the inherent mechanical complexity of a ICE drivetrain.
But for now... you can get a commute cuckbox, or you can buy a 8 seat Tesla. F150 would be interesting if it did not require a non commercial truck driver license in Europe.

An ev truck is based, especially as a work vehicle
> power export for your tools at the job site
> ladder chassis means lots of space for batteries meaning decent range
> even if you factor in the higher purchase price, maintenance and fuel will more than pay for the difference
> since you do work with it, you have a means to park it and have access to industrial power (400/480V 3 phase) to charge it overnight. Most sites have high power outlets as well (400V 3 phase in yurop, 240V "2" phase in the States.)
> high reliability = low downtime
> no idling
> all the tq you want for pulling
> usable frunk for the stuff you can't leave in the rear
> some trucks have through the vehicle tunnels that fits steel, pipes and 4x2, fucking useful if you work construction

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26249547
>Self service or pressure washer at home
>Spray until dirt is gone then use squeegee and shammy leather for the rest
Since I own an offroad-ish truck I don't really care much about dirt on the outside. As long as my headlights work and I can take a look out of the windows I'm fine.
I spend more time cleaning the interior
>Thick rubber mats on the floor
>Start by removing all the shit in the glove box and other compartments.
>vacuum clean the entire interior, combined with a soft brush for those hard-to-reach spots like rotary switches (pro-tip: Shaving cream brushes)
>Damp cloth to wipe over all surfaces to remove residual dust and other shit
>Use windex to clean glass and mirrors real good. I'm really anal about that.
>Put some light grease on the seat rails (sometimes)
>Use a piece of cloth with a light(!!!!!!!!) coat of Ballistol on all the plastic and rubber parts. After that it's necessary to let the truck air out for an hour to remove the Ballistol stench. But I found out it's a real good protection for plastics and rubber and also gives them a nice shine. Since I don't really soak the cloth they also don't get slippery/oily at all.
>Put all the stuff back into the glove box and other compartments.
>Top off windshield washing fluid if necessary
>Take a seat, put on the radio and drink a beer while enjoying the clean truck for a few moments.
That's my usual regimen. No fixed dates, more like "every other month or so if I think it's necessary"

>>26254081
in many europe countries cars over 2000 cc have a wealth tax, which means that you pay around 2 to 5% of the value of the car for about 10 years, every year, on top of the yearly road tax. This happens regardless if the car costs 10k or 100k, if it has a 2000 cc engine or more, you will pay that tax.
in these countries people are starved of high hp and that the reason they jump on those 1.4, 1.6, or 1.8 engines with turbos which are unreliable as hell, because buying a 3.0 litre NA car with the same hp as an 1.8 litre TSI from VAG costs something like 3k/year in taxes, while the 1.8 litre is less than 300.
in other countries here in eu, you are taxed based on your hp, that's why you see there many cars running some obscure diesels, like 2.2 litre, 1.9 litre, etc, that make 90hp, because it's cheaper on the taxes compared to a gasoline 1.2 TSI engine with 110 hp.
GR yaris is successful due to fitting well in the european car taxing system.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
general repair/diagnostics thread. Post what issues you're currently having with your car(s) or what you're planning on repairing. Give advice and help others out.

I'll start.

If you own mk1 p2 volvos like 1999-2005 s60s, s80s, v70s and etc and you have a bad idle you might want to install new sensors in your throttle body. The italian throttle body installed in the early versions used ancient technology that wear down over time and if you don't want to keep buying new ones for 700 dollars you can convert it with hall-sensors for 100 dollars and some time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26251511
Can you elaborate? My dad has a S70 2.5T that recently started running like shit

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26251518
I don't know if the s70 2.5t has these issues. Could have the same throttle body.

Basically
>italian Magneti Marelli etm/throttle body was used in most volvos early 2000s
>they kept breaking after around 150k km
>used an older type of sender that relays data to the car
>with time the sender's components break down and gives wrong data
>throttle body might in reality be 5% open but sensors will give back 2%
>computer compensates and the result is revs going from 1000-700 indefinetly
>results in entire throttle body needing replacement since car will die
>cleaning the etm will not help
>only solution is to buy new original italian etm or replace the sensors with solid state


So if you've looked through everything, pcv system, egr, vacuum leaks and all of that but the issue remains. Look at the throttle body and see if it is Magneti Morelli.

People might say that some of the updated throttle bodies are good, but in every updated version they kept the old sensors and they will fail eventually no matter what.

Here is a link to a kit: https://bjprace.se/bilmodell/volvo/rep-ombyggnadssats-volvo-magnetti-marelli-elspjall/

Site mentions that s70 turbos do use the magneti throttle bodies so worth checking out.

posts.com:
So way back in 2003, Honda made this commercial which features a long Rube-Goldberg machine. People were amazed and they claimed that it was done without CGI.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_ve4M4UsJQo [Embed]

The thing is though, while it may have been able to fool people in 2003, it's clearly CGI. Anyone with even a passing experience with how CGI looks and moves can tell these days that it was CGI. It looks like fairly impressive 2003 CGI, and it's even more obvious when objects get close to the camera.

They even made a phony BTS video to "prove" that it wasn't CGI, something that people in the comments will smugly point anyone to who says it's CGI: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Kh4zWeUDW-E. [Embed] This 8-minute video features about 2 seconds of the "real, raw footage" and is almost entirely taken up by the ad itself or people talking about how difficult it was to make.

Snopes even has an article that claims it was made without CGI, and their evidence is that.. some people said it was. Great work as always, Snopes. The same goes for the Wikipedia page.

It's just funny how this lie was able to fool so many people and Honda have seemingly never fessed up.

ahh the 3vz-e, the black sheep of the vz engine family. trd built a 400 hp one for baja or dakar or something. last time i saw it was on ebay, dunno who has it now.
iirc the ball joint thing was a design flaw on all early tacos and 96-04 4runners where the ball joint was constantly trying to get pulled out of its socket, causing earlier and more catastrophic failure compared to the revised design after this period where the ball joint is instead compressed into its socket. aftermarket parts would fail much earlier than the oem parts simply because the oem ones were just so much beefier so they gave more warning time before failing completely. The ball joints would also fail if the securing nut wasn't torqued to spec and in some cases people didn't use the cotter pin. The bolts also weren't reusable; who knows how many DIYers didn't know about this either.

>>26241426
yeah. took a day or two to nail the basics down. lots of stalling at lights and waving to the driver behind me kek. At one point while learning I was starting to regret swapping to a manual because I kept feeling like shit holding up everyone behind me.
one bro in a hilux must've put two and two together because he waved back three times in a sort of 'it's cool mate shit happens'
But there was no way I was going to put the auto back lol so I just kept at it. Once i realised i could increase the margin before the engine stalled by just keeping the revs at 1500-2000 rpm and slowly releasing the clutch at the same time, i think that was the moment where another anon in a recent thread described learning to drive manual as
>you keep practising until one day it randomly clicks and you never unlearn how to drive a manual ever again
i did about 2000 km in the past week or so just driving everywhere and nowhere and having an absolute blast. People kept telling me that manuals will suck in stop start traffic but honestly I didn't find it too bad. Just figure out the pace at which you can just crawl along.
Now it's a matter of refining the technique. Have gotten better and better at revmatching, but it'll be a while yet until i can do the manual racing memes like heel toe shifting and all that
pic related was when I initially installed the pedals. looked wonky as you can see, thankfully my work had a hydraulic metal bender which allowed me to get the pedals at the perfect position

Actually took about 9 months to build up the parts and i definitely overpaid on some of them but fuck it, im gonna drive this thing till the wheels fall off. then im gonna put them back on and drive it again
on a side note, the speedo no longer works because the little spring clip (pic related) that holds the speedo drive gear in place on the output shaft, has lost tension after 20 or so odd years of doing its thing. so i have to drop the gearbox again to replace it because it requires taking off the back half of the tranny. Once parts arrive, I'm going to go to a DIY garage because it's so much easier when you have an actual tranny jack. I've been gauging my speed with the tacho though. Really I just like to have everything working. While I'm at it I also have to replace the output shaft seal and revert back to the stock mk3 supra shifter retainer, because the sc300 one i used is a bit too far back. Anyone need it? I can sell the both the retainer and the shift lever arm

posts.com: the stock speaker on the drivers side of my 6th gen celica is starting to distort at medium volume, thinking of replacing it with an aftermarket. Found a good adapter already, but not sure what speaker brand I should put in? needs to be 6.5 inch 400 watt. I don't plan on adding an amp/sub addon, car is too rattly for it to have any serious sound system mods.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26248038
check the oem speaker impedance, iirc nips all use 4 ohm impedance speakers. should be on the back of the speaker itself, where the magnet is. if you install a different impedance speaker it'll be distorted.
If using with factory head unit, look for speakers with a high sensitivity. around 89 db is fine, but higher is always better. watts rms doesn't need to be too high with stock head units too.
I think toyota generally uses 5.25 inch speakers in the door, but take it out and confirm. And also confirm if it's a component or coax speaker, then pick from there.
Alternatively crutchfield has a speaker selector where you can pick what car you have and it'll give you options that fit

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26248548
Thanks. Impedance totally slipped my mind, Just checked and yeah they are 4ohm. I'm going by the size the adapter wants the speaker, since it was made for that model.
I'm thinking of replacing the head unit in the future (and even then, just for android auto, not for better amplification) but for now i'll stick with stock. Found a 400w 4ohm 6.5" coax 96dB speaker - Cerwin Vega V465, i'll install that. Thanks

Many of the first gen components are no longer in production, even consumables like the drive shaft carrier bearing assembly which has a unique rubber donut used only on the Century can't be bought anymore. Places like Nengun will list all the components but oftentimes the parts are NLA. I did find a place that might produce the rubber necessary just gotta contact them once I pull it off the car.

I can absolutely believe paying out the ass for an axel. What used parts you can find aren't usually that expensive but the freight is going to be killer. If you can snag one at 15 years old you're in much better condition than most of us in the US with 25+ year old ones. I can tell you at least the first gen century is well made and reliable and mine has over 400k km on the clock which is very unusual for a literal limousine. I imagine the second gen should be as reliable.

posts.com:
>>26251877
>Looks like a pasta, I def saw someone larping as a German car mechanic before
Nah he's right, another german mechanic here.
We do indeed get very much training during the entire apprenticeship.
You work in your company as an apprentice. Twice a week you need to go to trade school (Berufsschule) where they teach you hardcore theory of automotive technology, also maths and stuff like that.
Every few months your class will be sent to the chamber of crafts (Handwerkskammer) for courses which last about a week and each one has a different focus. For example "Diesel injection equipment" or "welding basics".
These courses are held by master craftsmen who work for the chamber and are really good at what they do.

So when youre finished after 3 1/2 years you are indeed a really skilled mechanic. You don't just now practical work but you got a solid theoretical foundation about the entire vehicle engineering, how shit works etc.

If you want more you can become a master craftsman yourself. That needs even more courses at the chamber, costs a fair bit of money. But I'd wager a German master craftsman doesn't know less than guys in other countries who got an engineering degree.

The Godfather hearse rolled back into the shop for a hemorrhaging trans leak. Of course, the seal was the one behind the viscous coupling, so I had to drop the trans. Hyrdamatic viscous couplings are sealed to the flywheel with a thin ass gasket and 38 bolts, which has to be the dumbest design I've ever seen. It's back in though.
Thanks for reading my blogpost

posts.name: laseranon
posts.com:
>>26252371
I actually couldn't tell you when they stopped using them, but I know they were developed in 1940, and this hearse is a '52, so they had quite a good run. The rest of the guts of the transmission are actually pretty solid and easy to work on, but I dispise the viscous coupling design. When pulling the motor or the trans, you have to drain 7qts out of the coupling and remove the nearly 40 bolts from the flywheel. And when re-installing it, you have to be absurdly careful to not bump or tear the thin paper torus gasket or you'll get the mother of all leaks since it's under a lot of pressure from the centrifugal force of the fluid spinning in the coupling.

posts.name: laseranon
posts.com:
>>26252611
It's not a torque converter since there is no reduction from the input to the output. It's just a viscous coupling that allows slippage between the front and back for the trans to shift while still being able to transfer power 1:1. There isnt a serperate rotor on the inside like there is in a TC, its just two halves of fins that rotate close to each other. So yeah, its more like a clutch, I suppose. That's not unique to this trans though, I've worked on a few others that have the same thing. Here's one out of a 50s Daimler I did a while back.
I doubt GM invented the concept, but I know they're definitely the first ones who ever used it in a production car.

posts.name: laseranon
posts.com:
>>26253207
A torque converter has a stator and has the ability to multiply torque at the output, sort of like a gear reduction. They're usually around a 2.5:1 reduction. A viscous coupling does not have a stator and can't multiply torque, it's best ratio is 1:1.
Also, >>26253215 is right. A torque converter uses the actual flow and direction of the fluid to transmit torque to the stator fins, whereas a viscous coupling simply uses the shear force of the fluid. I would assume it transmits power less efficiently than a torque converter, but I genuinely don't know.
>>26252978
Maybe, but I dont really think so. A torque converter gives the engine more mechanical advantage, especially if you're engineering a small economy car with a small engine.

Welp, it's official. The block on my '87 944S fragged the fucking block in cylinder 3 with (probably, because magnetic) piston ring fragments and some deep gouging, without an obvious culprit as to *why*.
I wasn't hooning around or doing anything retarded at the time of failure, or really, at all before that, even. Shop's best guesstimate right now is somewhere between 5k-10k when it's all said and done if we go that route. Said they THINK the head looks good, but they don't want to incur extra labor charge ripping it apart if I decide to cut bait on the car at this point, and that it would need to go to a machine shop for thorough crack checking, surfacing, etc, regardless. And, of course, it's an Alusil block that's a fucking specialty machine shop's job to even assess, then attempt, honing on (if that's even possible with the condition - sounds like we're 95% sure that's not possible).
Suggestions? Sell the fucking thing as a donor and wait for a good deal to come my way on something faster and a bit more modern (and NOT fucking 170k miles?)? Dump in potentially more than the 7k I originally paid for it a couple years ago to get it road worthy again? Do some serious begging on forums? (The #1 guy for 944 salvaging/scrapping ignored my messages about finding a block).
Also, I was under the impression the 944/944S/944Turbo had interchangable blocks post 86.5. Shop says that's not the case due to something relating to the DOHC on the S?
Feelsbadman. I loved that car. Remember kids, cars that are nearing 40 years old can go catastrophically wrong on the drop of a dime.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26254381
GT40 Mk I: 255ci Indy V8 in prototypes, 289ci Windsor in production models. 5 speed ZF gearbox
GT40 X-1: single chassis modified to a roadster, aluminium rather than steel for the chassis
GT40 Mk II: 427ci FE V8 replaced the 289ci, modified chassis to handle the increased weight. 4 speed Kar Kraft 'box
GT40 Mk III: road car version of the Mk II, 289ci Windsor paired with the ZF 5 speed 'box
J-car: brand new American-designed aluminium honeycomb chassis, new body and better aerodynamics. 427ci FE V8 and 4 speed Kar Kraft 'box
GT40 Mk IV: development of the J-car, 427ci FE V8 and Kar Kraft 4 speed 'box

>Manhattan, NYC

Dirt cheap, high mileage black Town Car
>First escape vehicle:
White Ford Transit Ecoboost/Chevrolet Express V8/duramax done up to look like a full on tradie van (with at least two or three sets of removable magnet company logos on hand), but with a decent quality low profile push bar since you're not getting through heavy traffic without moving people out of the way
>Vehicle swap for a highway chase:
Debadged W220 S55 AMG, an N54 powered BMW E60/F10 5 series or E70 X5, or an Ecoboost late model AWD Explorer. All are easily tunable for more power and cheap to pick up. A ~10 year old Grand Cherokee with a supercharged hemi or full-on Hellcat swap. You could exchange this for any of the 'highway chase' options too.

If I ever learned anything from watching movies such as Goodfellas, you never go out and blow cash after a heist especially on a new car. posts.name: Anonymous

>>26240044
The rally is an off-road endurance event. The terrain that the competitors traverse is much tougher than that used in conventional rallying, and the vehicles used are typically true off-road vehicles and motorcycles, rather than modified on-road vehicles. Most of the competitive special sections are off-road, crossing dunes, mud, camel grass, rocks, and erg among others. The distances of each stage covered vary from short distances up to 800–900 kilometres (500–560 mi) per day. "Amateurs" typically struggle with the event. The rough terrain and lack of skill usually results in accidents and serious injuries.

The Dakar rally features a much greater variety of vehicles than traditional rally's, including bikes, quads, and trucks. Dominant manufacturers within the Dakar Rally are KTM for bikes, Yamaha for quads and Kamaz in trucks. Out of the big three Kamaz are most notable as they have won using the largest variety of vehicles instead of sticking with a select few models. In 2006 a tracked vehicle category was proposed and rejected due to the necessary volume of sub-divisions to ensure fair competition. In 2018 an EV category was proposed, this to was rejected as "there currently exists no electric vehicle capable of crossing the most remote stages of the Dakar unsupported and it would place an unnecessary risk on support crews to enable them to do so", despite annual reviews and counter-claims this continues to be the case. In 2020 Volkswagen proposed an all-electric entry for the 2021 race and although accepted as a non-competing entry, failed to appear.

12.6 is acceptable resting voltage. Noisy starters are (you hope) just an elderly starter motor. When you remove that inspect the flywheel/flex plate gear teeth with a bright light.

If good, no worries so replace starter. Plenty of info online. Don't omit disconnecting the ground cable at the battery before molesting starter.

Over the tires is most secure because a bounce doesn't loosen straps. Soft slings and tire bridles are not required but worth a look.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26242898
If this is a BMW or Audi or similar German car, the batteries have to be coded in. You can't just pull the old battery and put the new battery in.
Assuming you covered that already then:
Have you explored parasitic electricity loss?
Go to the auto parts store and have them test your battery. If the battery looks good then I would suspect something is drawing power while the car is off

>>26242939
I wonder if your transmission mount is going? Mounts for the engine and the transmission and the drivetrain in general are supposed to flex a little to help keep vibration out of the cockpit, but if they deteriorate or are old, they can flex too much and cause lag and wheel jump and all sorts of nonsense.

>>26243166
Springs don't wear out whether they're compressed or extended, they only wear out with use, so if your goal is to preserve the life of your shocks I would tie it down so that it's compressed.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26245261
Could be a number of things but the most likley is that water (which is a byproduct from combustion) is precipitating in your cold exhaust pipe, and that when your exhaust heats up (as the engine does) it makes it out the end of the exhaust still in gaseous form. What you're seeing is condensation, not smoke. If it is smoke it could be your piston rings that seal better as your engine internals heat up, which causes your cold engine to consume a bit of oil.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26248477
We'll start with the most serious issue: The cracked block.
If it was cracked externally, you'd doubtless have found the leak by now.
If it was cracked internally, you definitely notice symptoms such as fluid contamination. Given you state that's not happening, nor is it building too much pressure, then I'm optimistic you can rule out the block/head/head gasket.

Likewise, if the EGR manifold/cooler assembly has started leaking, you'll be able to tell as exhaust gases would be present to some degree in the coolant, darkening it. If not darkening it, then a sniffer test would detect the presence of coolant. They're a simple kit to buy and use.

Failing that, we're left with the wet intake manifold as the most likely cause of the three you've listed.
Testing it (and the EGR manifold, if it comes to it) is easy - if a little awkward.
Basically block one pipe, and find some way to fit a tyre valve to the other. Inflate to 20 psi, use water/suds to make sure your pipe block/valve arent leaking and observe any pressure drop. Over, say, half an hour. A leaking component will have lost it's pressure.

Or you can remove the components completely, then submerge them like a tyre tube and look for bubbles.

Also, take out your spark plugs. If it's the EGR or the intake, then ALL the plugs should have signs of burning coolant.
If only one or two plugs have it, then it's an engine issue.
The coolant-fouled plug is on the right

posts.com: Does it help or hinder tire alignment that electric cars have 4 independent motors instead of one motor/driveshaft powering all the wheels? Debating with a friend, one of us thinks it's easier because each wheel can have sensors and adjust alignment as needed, one of us thinks it's worse because there's nothing mechanical keeping the system in sync.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26251509
>Electronic on-the-fly wheel alignment adjustment
Jesus I can't think of anything more horrifying. Luckily, I don't ever see that happening on mass market vehicles; the alignment will be held rigid by threaded bolt members or bolted eccentric cam washers.
Having four wheel motors won't have any effect on that setup because the motors will be "inboard", meaning they drive the wheels from inside the sprung mass of the vehicle, dividing the torsional stress of acceleration between the motor's mounts, the driveshaft and the suspension mounts.

Even if the motors were all hub mounted, the only thing it would do is increase the stress of acceleration on the suspension mounts, making them more likely to wear earlier, which could *then* impact alignment.
Stronger components/bushings would negate that, however.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26250095
On the 122, it's not really so simple. There's a manifold block that bolts to the side of the head, and this block is where the hot coolant flows out of the engine from and into the radiator. The thermostat housing bolts onto it, and it has the ports for the coolant level and the coolant temperature sensors. And also the EGR gasses flow through it (it does have vacuum modulated EGR). But, closing off the EGR valve would only prevent the EGR gasses from continuing into the intake, it would NOT prevent the EGR gasses from entering this manifold and potentially entering the coolant loop (if there is a crack here). So "ripping out the EGR" would involve at minimum some kind of blockoff plate custom made for the shape of this manifold, and the shadetree tools I've got don't extend to a mill. But believe me, I've thought about it.

posts.name: Sage
posts.com:
>>26240792

The L15B has poor engine oiling, tiny crankshaft with poor rod to stroke ratios which prevent the engine from wanting to rev. The rods are weak and bend or shatter above 250whp. They also have tiny rod bolts which are smaller than an average 10mm oil pan nut. This causes the bolts to fail under stress lunching the engine. The head bolts are undersized which cause head gasket problems. Everything about the engine is designed to be as cheap as possible and to save money on gas, not make power. The only people who defend them do it because they own a car with one in it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>26242123
based take. anyone defending the l15b is coping hard as fuck they can't experience a true honda enginea0

posts.name: Sage
posts.com:
>>26242193
They won't be making that much power for very long. Theres a video on YouTube that shows some differences between L15 parts and other honda engines like K20,D16 etc. The l15 crankshaft is about 2/3rds the size of a d16 crankshaft and has tiny balancers and small journals. The rods are much smaller than a k20 and the rod bolts are 3 sizes smaller. The oil galley grooves on the block mains are small and on the center main all oil pressure comes from a single pinhole. No crank girdle to be found. The oil pump gears apparently shatter with increased power or can score and lose oil pressure. The torque to yield head bolts are of a lower quality metal then the K series ones.

This isn't a case of "new engine bad", the l15b is a cost cutting economy engine Honda threw in its Civic SI to save costs and there aren't alot of safety margins built into it once you exceed stock output.

>So basically what you're saying is, everyone listing used vehicles SHOULD have this done already and if they don't its because they might be scumbags who are trying to trick the buyer into a super fucked up situation?
>The only good reason they shouldn't have it smogged is if they weren't actually planning on selling it.

I think its a slightly different set up. People list their cars for sale, they may not go and get it smog checked right away because if the car doesn't sell within 30 days or whatever the time frame is then they have to pay to do it again. My overarching point is that when you ask the owner for a smog cert they should say something like "I'll go and have it done". If there is any hesitation like "oh it'll pass don't worry." don't go forward with the transaction.

If you find a car you like and you're ready to buy, the previous owner should go get it checked, get the cert and transfer it over. Its really not a hard process at all, merely that people don't want to keep paying for checks if it doesn't sell right away.

The scumbags are the people who may try to persuade you into buying the car without giving you a valid smog check.

Blutooth dongle.

It’s kind of annoying because you’re going to have to pay for licenses and download different apps for certain cars, but for a $20 bluetooth module and ~$20 per car license purchases, you can get the functionality of like a $500+ scan tool.

This is from somebody who owns 2 standalone scan tools and recently got one of those Veepeak modules. The $25 Veepeak can send commands to change the damn radio station and my $150 Autel can’t do anything close to that.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26248083
>>26248091
But also the $20 bluetooth module with a free app will give you the function of a ~$50 standalone scan tool. You can still read typical codes and erase stuff. The $15-$25 license for each car (depending on the app, like there’s some good all around apps and some brand specific apps) will get you deep into the car’s computer. Before I bought that Veepeak, I was reading a lot of reviews and those are popular with BMW goys because they can reprogram shit with some Bimmer app and their smartphone.

So can’t really lose. It’s free to check basic codes on a friend’s car, and not that expensive if you have some retarded project where you need to go deep with diagnostics.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26249436
Also, that sounds horrifically slow. You must not know how flat rate pay works. I get paid one hour to diagnose a car regardless of how long it actually takes. The snap on software isn't just for CAN access, it's also the "intelligent diagnostics" that give you immediate access to test procedures, connector pinouts, system function descriptions, real fixes, smart data (watches relevant PIDs and dings when something irregular shows up), etc. That way I generally don't have to dick around on Mitchell/AllData/Identifix etc trying to find what I need, it's all right there while I'm standing next to the car. Also, it sounds like you don't have bidirectional functionality (basically the scan tool can force the car to do certain functions when I want, like commanding the fuel pump relay on or something). A lot of OEM diagnostic trees require this functionality. It's also a lab scope/multimeter, if you didn't catch that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26251148
Should be a good bike. I ride an older small block(small engine architecture, biggest is 850cc, smallest is 350).
Those have the same motor as the older v7, which is similar to my bike.
Breva has a nice brembo brakes, lightweight for a guzzi, good seating position, big tank, and the bigger ones have dual gauges+gas gauge, not sure about the 750.
Top speed is probably 100-120mph, cruise at 4000-5000rpm generally.
Easy maintenaince but drive shaft does mean you get a little more laborious maintenaince less frequently. Just inspecting and greasing splines should be done every tire change or every other change.

They sell cheap because it's not cool like the v7, but not fast enough like the 1000+cc bikes. Great beginner bike or commuter. Should get around 50+mpg.

Forums have great knowledge. If you live in europe should be an easy buy, but here in the states they are more of a DIY/wrencher bike unless you live next to one of the 10-20 dealers....

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26251369
First bike you will drop because everyone drops their bike either by slipping on gravel at 4mph or by coming to a stop woth the forks not straight. So just accept that you'll probably drop your bike.

Used in good condition from a private sale is the most economical choice. If you have friends that own bikes and know maintenance then rely on them.

Otherwise just get any bike you want. Dual sports tend to have higher seat heights so unless you're a lanket, a shorter bike will be easier to learn on. But you can learn to ride on dual sports so get what interests you.

Take MSF, sit on and test drive bikes, any bike is a good bike, so take the time to explore and choose what you want.

posts.com: How often do you clean/lube your chain? Do you just use Simple Green and old oil, or some sort of meme cleaner/lube?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26252450
Every 500 miles. 1000 max.
Kerosene or diesel to clean it. Dry it as well as you can. Chainwax lube sprayed onto sprocket side of chain. One good coat is enough. It's going to sling the extra off anyway.
The meme grunge brush works but it's nylon. Will work for a good condition chain. If your chain is rusty, or really bad, use a very fine steel or preferably brass.

>>26252562
Oh right, yeah don't use simple green. Won't do the job well enough and you don't want water based shit getting on/into your chain. I use simple green in my shop basically for wiping down doors, surfaces, etc that I greasy paws on. Kerosene will dissolve the grease on the chain much better and is not corrosive to the chain if you don't get it all off (you probably won't).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26254049
shieee my time has come
>Get it super clean with dish soap
ehh I wouldn't use a dish soap, it can leave smears all over the place.
try get a PH neutral actual car/bike wash. We want it clean and also NOT to put any more wax on the bike itself, which a lot of car washes do include
>Clay bar
ye clay bar time, honestly just use a spray bottle of water for lube, it works fine. Cool also if the bar comes with lube tho. After this, hit the bike panels with metho/wax and grease remover to make sure it's absolutely wax, oil and contaminant free
>Polish with some kind of hand applicator pad
yee, you can get all kinds of polish from light to full on compounds, but stick with light until you know what you're doing
>Apply wax with a different hand applicator pad
yee, wax time. basically choose whichever one you like. you can rate wax on 4 categories. ease of application, gloss, hydrophobicity and how long it lasts. Probably get carnauba, super easy on and off, usually a good show wax which means gloss will be great but it might not last very long (also probably the best choice on chrome finishes). you know it's time to buff the wax off if you run a finger through it, and it doesn't smear at all, just a solid clean line where your finger went
>apply some kind of restoration liquid on any black plastic
ye UV protectant. we all know how manky plastic trim gets from old cars by now, gross. also pro tip, never use "le heat gun life hack" on faded plastics. it makes them more brittle in the long run and it'll look shit again in a couple months
glhf

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
To all the retards here:
1st things first. Car's a BMW 118d cabrio from 2010 I use to shit on civics.
Mods include air intake, intercooler, turbo, piping, exhaust, EGR and DPF delete and an aggressive remap. I did all the mods myself only took the car in for the remap and dyno testing.
Should output between 230 to 250hp though the clutch is OEM and it should be quite worn down now but I'll have it replaced with a 4 puck race one next month.

I have already done some troubleshooting, such as:
>MAF
Was my initial thought since it's been raining a lot and my high flow air filter can allow moisture to pass through at high speeds. Though it's dry now, I disconnected and checked sensor, all good. Scanner doesn't show now and never showed any MAF errors.
>Injectors
This is my 2nd set, they don't even have 50k on them. 4th injector showed an error on the scanner but it could just be clogged from unburnt diesel. I added 2 bottles of injector cleaner additive to the fuel and it's not giving out errors anymore.
>Vacuum lines
Was one of my thoughts considering the turbo pressure was fluctuating between 0 and 1 psi on idle Pressure should be constant unless there are leaks. However I did a smoke test and couldn't find anything sucking in.
>Glow plugs
Last culprit. 2 of them show up faults on the scanner. It is definitely the reason for the hard starting when cold. Could be the reason for rough idling and hiccups at lower rpms. If the chamber doesn't heat up correctly, there could be misfires and fuel not being burnt properly, especially when I have the car remapped and there's nore fuel being injected. It explains why it hiccups at low rpms, when the turbo isn't building enough pressure and the ecu compensates with more fuel than it can be burnt.
>EGR valve
It's deleted so it can't be that

In the end I think it's the glow plugs. Retards at the shop told me they were fine even though they show up faults and one of them has a broken head and feels somewhat loose.

>>26252460
If your car is idling rough for longer than it takes for all cylinders to warm up, it's not a glow plug problem. If your car stalls going up a hill, it's not a glow plug problem. If your problem goes away after cleaning the injectors, it's not a glow plug problem.

Glow plugs are only used when the car is cold, and are shut off before or when the engine starts, because all they do is heat up the injected fuel when it's cold to aid in starting.

Ok /o/ I'm fully prepared to be called a retard in this thread but it's ok because I need the advice regardless

I bought 96 toyota celica (I do not watch scotty) a few years ago and a few months after it needed a new clutch kit installed. I just chalked this up to it being an old car and the clutch already felt kinda wobbly initially so this wasn't a huge surprise for me.

Car gave me essentially no issues for about 1.5 years when suddenly last month the clutch started slipping really badly again. Within the course of just a few weeks it got so bad that it literally couldn't move anymore on the very day I was gonna take it to the mechanic. I had to get it towed there and of course they told me the clutch is fucked and needs replaced.

I have the money to fix it again no problem but what the fuck am I doing wrong to have fucked the clutch up again? I don't think it's normal for a clutch to get fucked that badly in less than 2 years unless my previous mechanic somehow fucked something up really bad, or if I just suck at driving a manual. I'm pretty new to driving stick and this car is the first manual I've owned, I had my dad teach me how to drive it and I asked him if I'm doing anything incorrectly last time I drove his car (also a stick) and he said I was fine. Is there any common errors I might be overlooking when driving manual that could've led to the clutch getting fucked again so soon? I definitely don't want to have this issue again especially for something that might be my fault

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26249945
Your clutch fluid system may have been weak and the clutch was experiencing slip and slowly over time it wore out again. You should take a look at the clutch master/slave cylinder and see if you're getting the proper application. What about the diaphragm spring? Does that still have good tension.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26249945
Do you ever have the clutch halfway engaged? The pedal should either be fully pushed onto the floor, or all the way up. You shouldn't ever use half clutch.

>>26249955
Not op but I tend to do this when I get stuck in a traffic, what would be the right way to move slowly without shortening the clutch's lifespan?
>t. recently got license

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26250024

if you arent planning on moving for >10sec, pop it in Neutral

read the cars ahead of you, keep your RPMs within range for 1st when goin slow

clutch lifespan is affected by friction/erosion and wear from disconnecting and connecting the crankshaft and drivetrain.

as long as you are not stalling or engaging at wierd gear combos (think anything that would place load on the friction plate)

the master and slave cylinders transmit your foot actuation to the pressure plate/friction disc/flywheel if one goes out, you get incomplete diconnects ie rubbing, and once worn down enough, slippage

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26249975
Yeah dont rev when pressing the clutch down, also dont abruptly step of the gas when you need to clutch. Take is nice and easy. Also shifting as fast as possible isnt a great idea, aim to be precise instead.

Somewhat related to this: automatic gearboxes shift much harder when modified to hold more power.

There are many things on a car that provide comfort, but can be exchanged för reliability.

In March 2000, auto sport Magazine of Japan’s front page carried the story that MTCI Racing Team would enter the Mercedes-Benz CLK-LM for the upcoming JGTC season, the ultimate “GT1 prototype” racing against the Supras, Skylines, and NSXes. Little is known about the entry apart from Marco Apicella being appointed as the first driver.

However, somewhere along with the negotiations between MTCI and Mercedes-Benz, and perhaps in large part from the shame of the CLR’s massive failure at Le Mans in ‘99, the sale fell through. MTCI Racing Team would instead field a privately-built Porsche Boxster in GT300, with Apicella driving.

By season’s end, MTCI and its race team had collapsed into bankruptcy after the dot-com bubble burst. Chairman Yu Hayakawa was later arrested in 2002 for stock sales fraud. And save for its victory in the 1998 Suzuka 1000km, the Mercedes-Benz CLK-LM never raced in Japan

>>26238810
A prototype did compete in 1994. Team Taisan is a stalwart in Japanese motorsports, having formed in 1983 as a privateer team and owned by the Taisan Industrial Company, a global manufacturer of electronic solenoid pumps.

The team enjoyed much racing success throughout the earlier Group A eras with a battery of Nissan R32 GT-Rs, along with BMW M3s in the lower JTCC series.

Business was clearly booming, as the team rocked up to the 1994 season fielding a Ferrari F40 and an ex-Group C Porsche 962 prototype (chassis 962-164). Consider the absurdity: a genuine Le Mans legend rubbing doors with tin-top GT cars. It was an impressive show of force, perfectly encapsulating the excess of Japan’s booming economy and well-heeled motoring enthusiasts. Over five rounds, Taisan’s Porsche 962C and Ferrari F40 won one meeting each, although the championship was ultimately won by Masahiko Kageyama in the Calsonic Hoshino Racing GT-R.

The ‘300ZX-GTS’ in these photos, chassis #009, is a little different than some of the earlier cars. For a start, it’s not twin-turbo V6-powered. Instead, a Nissan VH-series V8 can be found ahead of the quick-change rear end.

Whether it was a spare car or a development car is where things get a little bit murky, but it’s one of only two cars built by Cunningham Racing originally configured for use with the V8 engine, not retrofitted afterwards as other cars were. This would have allowed it to race in the 1995 IMSA GTS-1 class (the VG engine was outlawed at the end of the ’94 season), but the car was reportedly sold to Japan before it competed in any US events In 1997, it had been entered in a couple of JGTC GT500 class races wearing Fedex logos, but did not enjoy any success. Today, in its restored condition, it features the iconic Cunningham Racing 12 Hours of Sebring-winning livery.

The rumble of a V8 in JGTC!

The sound of a roaring V8 and a distinct yellow figure, a sight that in 2002 was a far more familiar sight in the American Le Mans Series, but in that same year, the Autobacs All Japan GT Series had a similar sighting.

Entered by American car tuner ZIPSPEED, the Dunlop clad C4 was of a different breed to its more known Le Mans focused C5.R counterpart. Driven by Toshiyuki Yamamoto and Izumi Yoshida, the C4 struggled against its more suitable rivals, setting a 1:48.146 in its first qualifying session of 2002, in the All Japan GT Championship at Fuji Speedway and failing to qualify for the race while the polesitting #62 Vemac R&D Sport RD320R achieved a 1:32.379.

Four more races were attempted that year, however success never came the team's way, with the C4 making it to qualifying but never having enough speed to make the race.

posts.com:
The JGTC Honda that took on the 24 Hours of Nurburgring!

In 2004, a semi-works Honda programme enlisted a special car to take on the unique challenge that is the Green Hell. The team that year aimed for overall victory and as such acquired a car that could bring them that. That said car was the 2002 GT500 spec Honda NSX. The mid-engine car was already a proven victor in the All Japan Grand Touring Car Championship thanks to the three wins earned by Nakajima Racing, and one each by Mugen and Dome in the 2002 season.

The #3 Honda NSX was entered under the Sport Auto banner and was driven by Armin Hahne, Robert Lechner, Markus Oestreich, and Robin Liddell. A few changes were done to the car to accommodate Nurburgring and the length of the race. One of those changes was the V6 engine being down tuned from the JGTC regulated 500hp to 420hp for reliability. Other changes include endurance lights and Michelin tires of which the car never ran on in the JGTC. The NSX weigh a minimum of 1200kg as par the rules of A6, the class the Honda competed in at Nurburgring.

The #3 Sport Auto NSX had a small amount of kilometres under its belt before contesting the 24 Hours of Nurburgring. Lack of testing however didn't stop the German squad from placing inside the top 15 in qualifying, showing the potential of a JGTC car in uncharted territory. The NSX successfully started the race keeping up with the cars ahead of it which included DTM derived machinery from Audi and Opel. The car however experienced technical problems early in the race and completed 38 laps/7 hours before retiring. https://youtu.be/LRKIAK5Yw3w

>Toyota made history by winning the 2007 Tokashi 24-Hour Race with its Supra HV-R hybrid race car. It is the first time ever that a Hybrid race car has won a competition.

The Supra’s success follows an entry the previous year when Toyota was the first car manufacturer to enter a hybrid vehicle – the Lexus GS450h – into the Tokashi 24-Hour race which finished 17th overall. By entering hybrid systems into racing events, Toyota engineers hope to discover ways to make hybrid systems, most famously fitted to the Toyota Prius production car, more efficient and lighter. In only the second year of competition Toyota used – with success – the data gained from last year’s race in order to develop a new, special racing unit to the limits of hybrid performance.

The race car was based on the iconic Supra GT used in Super GT races in Japan. It was modified and equipped with a special racing hybrid system. In order to improve the system’s energy regeneration and operating efficiency during the race, the following two distinctive technologies have been incorporated into it:

A four-wheel energy regeneration and drive system has been adopted which includes in-wheel motors in the front wheels in addition to one 150 kW rear-axle mounted electric motor. Thanks to this energy regeneration system with three motors/generators, the vehicle can more efficiently recover a greater amount of energy during rapid deceleration and braking from high speeds.

In light of the fact that racing involves a repeated acceleration and deceleration under full system performance, a quick-charging capacitor system was adopted instead of the usual rechargeable batteries.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Every modern McLaren, from the 2011 MP4-12C to the P1 to the 720S is powered by a single family of twin turbo V8s. This engine didn’t come out of nowhere; it started life in a largely-forgotten supercar from Nissan.

This is the Nissan VRH35L. It’s a twin-turbo 3.5 liter aluminum V8 used for endurance racing at Le Mans, the final line of development of Nissan’s VRH35 architecture that debuted in ‘89. Nissan and Tom Walkinshaw Racing (TWR) put the VRH35L together for their entry into the madcap GT1 category back in 1997 in the R390 GT1.

Engine weight was 170 kilos (just over 374 pounds), which I assume counts the weight of the two IHI turbos. Nissan claims its torque figure was “over” 520 lb-ft and horsepower was somewhere around 640 in race trim, 550 for the street-legal homologation specials mandated by the rules.

I do mean specials; only one street R390 GT1 got built, rebodied and VIN-swapped from red to blue, which never made it out of Nissan’s hands.

Nissan was never quite able to eke out a win at Le Mans with the R390 GT1, much as it had never quite been able to get an overall victory in its thousand-horsepower Group C years.

After running in 1997, 1998 and 1999, Nissan peaced out of the 24 Hours of Le Mans’ top classes and the whole effort has fallen into a dusty part of history in a way that, say, Porsche’s 1990s campaigns did not.

But the engine lives on still! Early on in the development of the old MP4-12C, McLaren picked out the VRH35 for the basis of its engine program and bought the rights to it from TWR, as Car and Driver reported at the time. McLaren and their engine builder Ricardo did a great deal of work to the design and basically made the thing their own, renaming it the M838T.

>>26245054
With the all-new Group C sports car regulations due to be introduced the following year, the 1981 season turned out to be an interim year. The leash on the Group 6 prototypes was already loosened to allow manufacturers to run new engines and/or cars a year early. Porsche used this opportunity to test the engine for the upcoming 956 Group C car in anger during the 24 Hours of Le Mans. One of their privateers, Kremer Racing used the same loophole for Le Mans, not to look ahead but to bring an old legend out of retirement; the Porsche 917.

The Group 6 regulations of 1972, which stipulated a three-litre displacement limit, had rendered the 917 obsolete from World Championship event. In the following decade, Kremer Racing actually restored one of the original 917s for a customer, so they had intimate knowledge of the twelve-cylinder engined racer. The two Kremer brothers reckoned there was life left in the design, especially if it was updated to suit the latest tyre technology. So, instead of bringing one of the existing cars out of retirement, Kremer Racing decided to build a brand new 917, with support from Porsche.

One of the main reasons to start from scratch was that Kremer reckoned the original all-aluminium spaceframe chassis would no longer be up to the task. Already stressed to and at times beyond its limits, the lightweight frame was likely not capable of dealing with the much higher loads produced by 1981-specification, slick tyres. Using the drawings supplied by Porsche and a higher gauge material, a new, sturdier frame was built. The new chassis tipped the scales at 65 kg compared to 50 kg of the original. The suspension geometry was also altered to make the most of the latest tyre technology.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Porsche offered Kremer Racing a choice of two versions of the Type 912 engine. The first was the 4.5-litre unit of the flat-12 that had powered the 917 early in its career and the second was the larger, 5-litre engine fitted to the later developments. While the second option was obviously more powerful, it was also thirstier. Taking into consideration the particular needs of the Le Mans track with its long straights, the Kremers understandably opted for power over frugality. Producing around 600 bhp, the big engine was mated to the tried and trusted five-speed gearbox.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The design and construction of the new 917 K/81 (K was for Kremer this time, not Kurz) took longer than expected, so the aerodynamics had to be rushed. Naturally, the original design of the 917 was carried over but again changes were made to incorporate the latest ideas in aerodynamics. Ideas was the best description as there was no time to actually test the final package in the wind-tunnel. Among the most obvious alterations were the removal of rounded lower sections of the body in favour of slab sides to help generate some ground effect. A full width rear wing was fitted, mounted between two sizeable tail fins.

With backing from French real estate company Malardeau Enterprises and BP, the 917 K/81 was fielded by Kremer Racing for the all-French line-up of Bob Wollek, Xavier Lapeyre and Guy Chausseuil. With the exception of a brief shakedown at the Nürburgring, the car was untested. As a result, it suffered from a variety of problems, in particular on the important long straights where the 917 barely breached the 300 km/h barrier. This was partly addressed by changing the gear ratios but it was also obvious that there were also aerodynamic problems.

With a qualifying time that was a full 17 seconds slower than the pole-sitting works Porsche, the new 917 started the race back in 18th. A steady run saw the car move into the top ten during the opening hours of the race but it then hit a variety of problems. It was finally forced to retire after seven hours following an off that had damaged an oil line, eventually resulting in terminal damage to the engine. By that time, a grief-stricken Bob Wollek had already left the track following the fatal accident of his close friend Jean-Louis Lafosse.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Repaired, Kremer's 917 was brought out once more for the Brands Hatch 1000 km of the World Championship. Shared by Wollek and Henri Pescarolo for the occasion, the car proved better suited to this track and even took the lead briefly. Sadly, it was prompted to retire once more, this time with a suspension failure. This really was the end of the contemporary racing career of the Porsche 917 as the one-off machine was retired and displayed as the centrepiece in the Kremer Racing showroom.

Skylines used the RB until 2003, then Nissan switched to a twin turbo VQ30. The 2003 spec car raced only for that season, the following year it got replaced by the Z33 running the same engine.

>>26243737
>There’s no reason to get a minivan if you can get an SUV instead.
Not exactly. To match the utility case of a minivan, which is occupancy between 1-8 passengers and/or up to 140-150 cubic feet of cargo room, the SUV in question has to be a full-size, extended length SUV, otherwise the comparison isn't fair.

I'm going to use new cars so as not to complicate the data. The most common full-size, extended length SUV is a Chevrolet Suburban. It starts at $55,000. The most common minivan is a Toyota Sienna, which starts at $36,135. This is an immense price difference just in purchase costs, not to mention insurance, registration, and operations costs. The appropriately matched SUV simply costs more to own than a minivan.

Now, there are use cases where a minivan is the wrong tool for the job. This would be towing over 3.5k lbs and 4x4. In that case, a SUV makes sense.

This comparison also ignores that minivan buyers are extremely price conscious, and recommending too much car to them tends to make them very upset. They will notice every time they fill up the fuel tank. They will notice every oil change. They will notice tires, brakes, and all manner of other consumables, not to mention rego, insurance, repairs, etc. SUV buyers also tend to attach a particular status to the vehicle they drive and as a result are more willing to go high dollar for them, or modify/personalize them with high dollar items. As comedians have overplayed, minivan buyers don't quite give a shit, which is why they drive them. They just want the practicality.

The buyer for a minivan and a buyer for a comparable SUV are not the same people at all.
